lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six objects (mobile phone, lunchbox, ring, watch, key, glasses) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Play “What’s Missing?” with flashcards (e.g. mobile phone, glasses). Show all, cover one, and ask: “What’s gone?”
stretchStrategies: Appearance Detective – Students play a “Who am I?” game. One student secretly chooses a person card, the class asks yes/no questions: “Is he tall?” “Is she young?” until they guess correctly. Builds vocab + grammar Q&A.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about objects using “Whose... is this?” / “Whose... are these?” and respond with “It’s ___’s.” / “They’re ___’s.”
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Use classroom items (real or picture cards). Ask: “Whose is this?” Students answer: “It’s Nam’s watch.” Swap roles in pairs.
stretchStrategies: Appearance Detective – Students play a “Who am I?” game. One student secretly chooses a person card, the class asks yes/no questions: “Is he tall?” “Is she young?” until they guess correctly. Builds vocab + grammar Q&A.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structures “Whose ___ is this? It’s ___’s ___.” and “Whose ___ are these? They’re ___’s ___.” to talk about possessions.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write question frames on the board: “Whose ___ is this?” and “Whose ___ are these?” Use a mystery box to practise ownership.

items: The -ing is often forgotten. Vietnamese does not have different forms of the same verb. I like eat rice.
VYL: many words starting in sibilants prove extremely difficult (shirt, shorts, socks, shoes). Plurals for singular items (trousers, shorts)
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
